Description: Tall and slender jar of Nile silt pottery with small flat base, slightly convex cylindrical shape, narrowing below everted rim; coated with red slip on the exterior and interior rim and burnished. Decoration in cream paint is modern addition.
Cultures/periods: Predynastic (Naqada I-IIB for jar, not decoration)
Curator's comments: The added decoration shows two identical boats in typical Naqada II style with two cabins, tree at the prow and standards; however, the oars are painted without the usual space in the center. Above the boats are spikey zig-zag lines rather than the more usual wavy lines. The lower body is painted with two elongated Naqada plants and two elongated skin on pole motifs. The presence of Naqada II style motifs applied in white paint on this red polished jar was initially seen as evidence that the Naqada I and Naqada II cultures were separate entities that overlapped in time, and this generated much discussion, which can now be discounted as the decoration is now considered to be have been added in modern times to an authentic pot of Naqada I-early Naqada II date. Vessel shape is like Polished red ware P66 in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921) Published: A Scharff, Some Prehistoric Vases in the British Museum and Remarks on Egyptian Prehistory, JEA 14 (1928), p. 262-3; pl. xxvi. J. Vandier, Manuel d’Archaeologie Egyptienne, Paris, (1952), p. 348-9.
